cards.title: Bandwidth vs Latency
cards.content: Internet speed has two parts. Bandwidth is the *width* of the pipe (how much water can flow at once). Latency is the *speed* of the water (how fast a drop gets from A to B). If you have high Bandwidth but high Latency, you can download a huge movie fast, but your online game will lag. The movie buffers (fills the pipe), but the game needs instant reaction (speed). Satellite internet often has good bandwidth but terrible latency because the signal has to travel to space and back. For gaming, you want low latency (Ping).
cards.keyTakeaway: Bandwidth is volume; Latency is travel time.

quiz.question: Which is more important for real-time online gaming?
quiz.explanation: Gaming requires instant data transfer (low delay), whereas downloading files cares more about volume.

cards.title: Open Source
cards.content: Imagine if Coca-Cola published their secret recipe and said, 'Anyone can cook this, change it, and sell it.' That is Open Source software. Linux, Android, and Firefox are open source. Anyone can see the code. Why do this? Because thousands of volunteers fix bugs faster than one company can. Most of the internet runs on Linux. It’s a collaborative utopia where people build tools for the common good. Opposed to 'Closed Source' (like Windows or iOS), where the code is a locked trade secret. The web is built on sharing.
cards.keyTakeaway: Open Source means the software code is free for anyone to use and improve.

quiz.question: Which of these is an example of Open Source?
quiz.explanation: Linux code is publicly available for anyone to inspect, modify, and distribute.

cards.title: Phishing
cards.content: Hacking isn't usually typing furious code like in the movies. It’s usually just asking you for your password. This is Phishing. You get an email: 'Netflix: Payment Failed. Click here.' You click, see a fake Netflix login page, and type your password. The hacker records it. They didn't hack Netflix; they hacked *you*. It’s called 'Social Engineering.' The weakest link in any security system is always the human. Always check the sender's email address (e.g., if it says 'netflix-support@gmail.com', it’s a scam).
cards.keyTakeaway: Phishing tricks you into voluntarily giving up your password.

quiz.question: What is the most common way hackers get passwords?
quiz.explanation: It is much easier to trick a human into typing their password than to break encryption.

cards.title: Blockchain
cards.content: Forget crypto for a second. Imagine a Google Doc that everyone can read and write to, but *nobody* can delete or edit what is already written. That is a Blockchain. It’s a digital ledger shared across thousands of computers. To cheat, you'd have to hack 51% of those computers at the exact same time (impossible). This creates 'Trustless' systems—you don't need a bank to verify a transaction; the math verifies it. It’s a way to keep records that are permanent and un-hackable. Bitcoin is just the first app to use this tech.
cards.keyTakeaway: Blockchain is a shared digital record that cannot be altered.

quiz.question: What makes Blockchain secure?
choices: A: It is hidden in a vault
B: The data is distributed across many computers and cannot be edited
quiz.explanation: Decentralization prevents any single entity from altering the record.

cards.title: 5G Explained
cards.content: People are scared of 5G towers. What is it? It’s just radio waves, like 4G, but at a higher frequency. Higher frequency means it can carry way more data (speed!), but the waves are shorter, so they can't travel as far or penetrate walls well. That’s why 5G towers need to be everywhere—on every lamppost—because the signal is fragile. It’s not mind control; it’s just physics. It allows for things like remote surgery and self-driving cars that need instant data without lag. It’s faster, but shorter-range.
cards.keyTakeaway: 5G is faster than 4G but has a shorter range.

quiz.question: Why does 5G require more towers than 4G?
choices: A: The signal doesn't travel as far
quiz.explanation: Higher frequency waves have shorter wavelengths and get blocked easily by obstacles.

cards.title: RAM vs Hard Drive
cards.content: Computers have two types of memory. Think of your computer like a kitchen. The Hard Drive is the pantry: it stores all your ingredients (files) permanently. It’s huge but slow to access. RAM (Random Access Memory) is the countertop: it’s where you put the ingredients you are cooking with *right now*. It’s super fast but small. When you turn the computer off, the countertop (RAM) gets wiped clean. More RAM means a bigger countertop, so you can do more things at once without running back to the pantry.
cards.keyTakeaway: RAM is for active tasks; Hard Drive is for long-term storage.

quiz.question: When you turn off your computer, what happens to the data in RAM?
quiz.explanation: RAM is volatile memory; it needs power to hold data.

cards.title: The Dark Web
cards.content: The 'Dark Web' sounds like a villain's lair. In reality, it’s just the part of the internet not indexed by Google. You need a special browser (like Tor) to see it. Tor bounces your signal around the world to hide your identity. While it is used for crime (buying drugs, hire-a-hacker), it is also used by journalists, activists in dictatorships, and whistleblowers to communicate safely without government censorship. It’s not inherently evil; it’s just private. It’s the digital equivalent of a meeting in a basement with the lights off.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Dark Web is encrypted and hidden from search engines.

quiz.question: Can you access the Dark Web with a standard Chrome browser?
choices: B: No, you need special software
quiz.explanation: It requires specific software like Tor to access the encrypted networks.

cards.title: Pixels
cards.content: Look closely at your screen. Closer. You see millions of tiny colored dots? Those are pixels (Picture Elements). Each pixel is actually made of three tiny lights: Red, Green, and Blue (RGB). By mixing these three lights at different intensities, your screen can make 16 million colors. Yellow is just Red + Green lit up together. White is all three on full blast. Black is all three turned off. Your entire digital life—every movie, photo, and meme—is just a mosaic of three colors tricking your eye.
cards.keyTakeaway: Every color on your screen is a mix of Red, Green, and Blue.

quiz.question: How does a screen make the color yellow?
choices: A: By turning on a yellow light
B: By mixing Red and Green lights
quiz.explanation: Screens use additive color mixing (RGB). Red + Green light = Yellow light to the human eye.

cards.title: Trojan Horse
cards.content: A Trojan Horse is a type of malware named after the Greek myth. The Greeks couldn't enter Troy, so they hid inside a giant wooden horse gift. The Trojans brought it inside, and the Greeks attacked. In tech, a Trojan is a virus disguised as a useful program. You download a 'Free Screensaver' or 'Game Crack.' It works, but inside, it carries a hidden payload that steals your passwords or spies on you. Unlike a Virus, a Trojan doesn't replicate itself; it relies on *you* to invite it in. Don't accept gifts from strangers.
cards.keyTakeaway: Malware disguised as legitimate software.

quiz.question: Does a Trojan Horse virus replicate itself?
choices: B: No, it relies on the user to download it
quiz.explanation: Trojans must be installed by the user (usually by trickery), unlike worms or viruses which spread on their own.

cards.title: Turing Test
cards.content: Alan Turing, the father of AI, proposed a test in 1950. A human judge chats with a computer and a human (via text). If the judge cannot tell which is which, the computer has passed the Turing Test. For decades, this was the gold standard of AI. Today, LLMs like ChatGPT pass it easily. We are now in a post-Turing world where 'sounding human' is easy. The new challenge isn't intelligence; it's truth. A machine can lie convincingly. We need new tests for consciousness and accuracy, not just imitation.
cards.keyTakeaway: A test to see if a computer can fool a human into thinking it's human.

quiz.question: A computer passes the Turing Test if:
choices: A: It solves a math problem instantly
B: A human cannot distinguish it from another human
quiz.explanation: The test measures a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

cards.title: Deepfakes
cards.content: You see a video of the President saying something crazy. It looks real. It sounds real. It's fake. Deepfakes use 'Generative Adversarial Networks' (GANs). Imagine two AIs: The Forger and The Detective. The Forger creates a fake image. The Detective spots the flaws. The Forger learns and tries again. They do this millions of times until the Forger creates a fake so perfect the Detective can't spot it. This technology is growing faster than our ability to detect it. In the future, 'seeing is believing' will no longer be true.
cards.keyTakeaway: AI-generated fake videos created by two AIs competing against each other.

quiz.question: How do Deepfakes improve so fast?
choices: B: Two AIs compete against each other to perfect the fake
quiz.explanation: GANs involve a generator and a discriminator network competing to create the most realistic output.

cards.title: The Singularity
cards.content: This is the ultimate sci-fi concept. The Singularity is a hypothetical point in the future when technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible. It happens when we create an AI that is smarter than humans. That AI then builds a *better* AI, which builds an even *better* one. Intelligence explodes. We can't predict what happens after that because we can't understand a mind smarter than ours—just like a dog can't understand the internet. Will it be utopia? Or Terminator? We don't know, but many think we are getting close.
cards.keyTakeaway: The moment AI becomes smarter than humans and improves itself uncontrollably.

quiz.question: What happens after the Singularity?
choices: B: It is impossible to predict (technological explosion)
quiz.explanation: It refers to an event horizon beyond which human prediction fails due to the emergence of superintelligence.
